dt: {bc}feeling withdrawn or separated from others or from society as a whole {bc}affected by {d_link|alienation|alienation}

dt.t: … after the success of 1969's "Easy Rider," a paean to the {wi}alienated{/wi} youth of the hippie generation …

shortdef: feeling withdrawn or separated from others or from society as a whole : affected by alienation

dt: {bc}to cause to be estranged {bc}to make unfriendly, hostile, or indifferent especially where attachment formerly existed

dt.t: He {it}alienated{/it} most of his colleagues with his bad temper.
Her position on this issue has {wi}alienated{/wi} many former supporters.

dt: {bc}to convey or transfer (something, such as property or a right) usually by a specific act rather than the due course of law
{bc}to cause to be withdrawn or diverted

pt: {sc}estrange{/sc} {sc}alienate{/sc} {sc}disaffect{/sc} mean to cause one to break a bond of affection or loyalty. {sc}estrange{/sc} implies the development of indifference or hostility with consequent separation or divorcement.
{sc}alienate{/sc} may or may not suggest separation but always implies loss of affection or interest.
{sc}disaffect{/sc} refers especially to those from whom loyalty is expected and stresses the effects (such as rebellion or discontent) of alienation without actual separation.

et: borrowed from Latin {it}aliēnātus,{/it} past participle of {it}aliēnāre{/it} "to transfer (goods, property) to another, lose possession of, render hostile, estrange," verbal derivative of {it}aliēnus{/it} "not one's own, of others, foreign, strange" {ma}{mat|alien:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: to cause to be estranged : to make unfriendly, hostile, or indifferent especially where attachment formerly existed
to convey or transfer (something, such as property or a right) usually by a specific act rather than the due course of law
to cause to be withdrawn or diverted
